author: jgm
content:
Biometrics should *never* be used to generate private keys.  Far too low entropy, and too easy to copy.

(They could be used to generate an identifier perhaps, although the entropy problem still exists.  But that's a different discussion.)

author: carlbeek
content:
agree with <@!144468805697929216> here, it's not workable without trusted 3rd parties.

faceID works because apple controls the interface so you can't brute-force against the underlying keys, only by putting lots of faces in front of a phone.

the entropy in a biometric auth system is very low. part of this is because it is hard to identify many distinguishing physical features. the other part is because you need to allow for physical changes over time & measurements.

also, biometrics cannot be revoked or reissued, you'd be permanently tied to a set of keys.

author: jgm
content:
<@!876973674564030504> I'm afraid you are misunderstanding the terms of the contract you agreed to when you carried out a deposit.  UKJT stated (note this was an opinion not the law, although it does carry significant weight) that a smart contract has many similarities to a traditional contract, and can indeed carry the force of law.  However, you don't get to make up the terms of the contract.  The deposit contract has very clear terms, explicit and laid out above in my previous text.  By sending a signed transaction (also note that UKJT stated that a signature does have legal force) you agreed to those terms.

Regardless of the provenance of the contract, you cannot add terms that you think should be to it after the fact.  You think the contract says one thing, and in fact it says another.  There is no work to be done to "fix" lost keys because they do not fall under the remit of the contract.
